newsitem.title: USA: Hess Oil fined $5.3 million for waste.
newsitem.headline: Hess Oil fined $5.3 million for waste.

text.p: The operators of the western hemisphere's largest oil refinery paid $5.3 million in fines on Monday after pleading guilty to transporting hazardous waste to Arizona from the U.S. Virgin Islands.

The U.S. Attorney's office in Newark, New Jersey, said the court clerk's office received two checks from the Amerada Hess Corp on behalf of Hess Oil Virgin Islands Corporation (HOVIC), which pleaded guilty last Tuesday to transporting 600,000 pounds (272,200 kg) of benzene-containing waste.

HOVIC admitted that between Dec. 11, 1991 and Feb. 9, 1992 it knowingly shipped as non-hazardous waste about 1,400 55-gallon (208-litre) drums containing "spent" refinery catalyst that exceeded the regulation limit for benzene.
The drums were shipped to a cement plant in Rillito, Arizona from St Croix in the U.S. Virgin Islands.
HOVIC is the refining arm of Amerada Hess Corporation, which has its primary offices in Woodbridge, New Jersey and New York.

"HOVIC operates the largest oil refinery in the western hemisphere and it certainly has the resources to comply with environmental regulations," Jeanne Fox, an administrator for the federal Environmental Protection Agency said in a statement after the company pleaded guilty last week. "There is simply no excuse for this company's failure to comply with federal hazardous waste regulations."

According to the plea agreement, the company paid a $3 million fine -- the maximum penalty under the law of $50,000 per day for each day of the 60 days the company violated the law -- and an additional $2.3 million in restitution as community service.
